source:
1. Data
   A. Clearly describe what the dataset is and why it's interesting:
   
This dataset explains global commodity trading stats, allowing me to look at various price fluctuations in different markets within different industries within different countries. For example looking at steel, fruits, or perhaps oils. Trade prices are in USD and I can examine various quantities of export and import within certain economies at different stages of development. The data spans 30 years and ends in 2016

   B. Link to the dataset
   
   https://www.kaggle.com/unitednations/global-commodity-trade-statistics
   
2. Research Design
   A. Proposal has clear research or business question
   
I am interested in exploring the 20 year trend in exported commodities from China between 1990 and 2010. 

   B. Identify at least one hypothesis they plan to test
   
Ho: There is no significant relationship between the average quantity of Chinese exported goods in 1990 and the average quantity of Chinese exported goods in 2010

Ha: There is a significant relationship between the average quantity of Chinese exported goods in 1990 and the average quantity of Chinese exported goods in 2010

   C. State how I will test my hypothesis using my data
   
Seeing as I will be using the variables quantity, country, and year, I will need to use an ANOVA test because I will be using more than two variables. Also I will create a histogram to visualize the changes in commodity trades between 1990 and 2010, including the means, and the confidence level calculation as well. 

3. Audiance

   A. Outline the user or stakeholder that this research will be valuable for
   
These findings would be helpful for economic policy makers, trying to reduce US reliance on Chinese exports. 

   B. Identify why audience will benefit from researchâ€™s findings
   
My audiance would benefit because they would be able to track exactly how reliant the US became over that 20 year period and measure our level of reliance as well, that way making a case for diversifying our imports.
